content: Church in SingaporeChurch in Singapore , Singapore **St George's Church** ([Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 圣乔治教堂; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Shèng Qiáozhì Jiàotáng*) is an [Anglican church](/wiki/Anglican_church) located on Minden Road in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)'s [Tanglin Planning Area](/wiki/Tanglin), off [Holland Road](/wiki/Holland_Road,_Singapore). Constructed between 1910 and 1913, the church was built for the [British troops](/wiki/British_Armed_Forces) stationed in Tanglin Barracks which was once the General Headquarters of the [British Far East Land Forces](/wiki/British_Far_East_Command). The church's community comprises members from [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) and many other countries. They are bound by a common desire to follow [Jesus Christ](/wiki/Jesus_Christ), and to seek [God](/wiki/God)’s purpose for their lives. ## Leadership St. George's Church is a parish of the [Anglican Diocese of Singapore](/wiki/Anglican_Diocese_of_Singapore). The present [vicar](/wiki/Vicar_(Anglicanism)) is Revd. Dr Jonathan Wong. He is supported by Revd. Paul Tan (Auxiliary Priest). The previous [vicars](/wiki/Vicar_(Anglicanism)) of the church include Revd. Canon Lewis Lew, Revd. Ian Hadfield, Revd. Mark Roland Dickens, Revd. Canon Philip Sinden, Revd. Mervyn Moore (acting [vicar](/wiki/Vicar_(Anglicanism))), Revd. Loren Fox, Revd. Paul Corrie, Revd. John Benson, Bishop [Dudley Foord](/wiki/Dudley_Foord) (interim, [vicar](/wiki/Vicar_(Anglicanism))), Revd. [Bruce Winter](/wiki/Bruce_W._Winter), and Revd. Bob Robinson. ## History **Origins of the Church building – Serving the British military in Singapore** St. George's Church was constructed from materials imported from [England](/wiki/England) and cost [£](/wiki/Pound_(currency))2,000 to build. The land was formerly used as a [nutmeg](/wiki/Nutmeg) [plantation](/wiki/Plantation) and it included Mount Harriet, a 103-foot high hill on which the church now stands. The land belonged to William E. Willan and was sold in 1865. However, even before the church was built, an [ordained](/wiki/Ordination) [minister](/wiki/Minister_of_religion) for the garrison was appointed in 1871. The current building dates back to 1910 but there was an earlier St. George's built in 1884 near the site of the present church. Both churches were built for the [British troops](/wiki/British_Armed_Forces) quartered at Tanglin Barracks which was once the General Headquarters of the [British Far East Land Forces](/wiki/British_Far_East_Command). After the [British forces](/wiki/British_Armed_Forces) withdrew from [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) in 1968, the place was used by Singapore's [Ministry of Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Singapore)) as its headquarters before it moved to its new premises in [Bukit Gombak](/wiki/Bukit_Gombak) **From Military to Civilian Church** St. George's became a civilian church after the [British troops](/wiki/British_Armed_Forces) left [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) in 1971. It was [gazetted](/wiki/Gazette) a [national monument](/wiki/National_Monuments_of_Singapore) by the [National Heritage Board of Singapore](/wiki/National_Heritage_Board_(Singapore)) on 10 November 1978, and now serves a multinational Christian congregation in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). **Major Ivan Lyon Memorial** On the outside of the church is a memorial tablet to Major [Ivan Lyon](/wiki/Ivan_Lyon) D.S.O. M.B.E., who was killed on his second commando raid on military shipping in the Singapore Harbour in October 1944. At the time of the raid, [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) was more than 1,000 miles inside Imperial Japanese-held territory. ## Services There are three regular services conducted on Sundays and one on Wednesdays. All involve lay participation: - At 8 am on Sundays and 10:30 am on Wednesdays, A more traditional [Holy Communion](/wiki/Eucharist) service following the [Anglican](/wiki/Anglican) liturgy, with hymns from *Common Praise*. - At 10:15am, an informal service with a mix of modern songs and hymn, lead by a band, suitable for families; [Holy Communion](/wiki/Eucharist) on the third Sunday of every month or at specific during Holy Week, happens after the Communion service - At 5:30pm, an informal contemporary service; [Holy Communion](/wiki/Eucharist) on the first Sunday of every month, happens on afternoons after the Japanese service. The [Filipino](/wiki/Filipino_people) Fellowship meets at the Lower Hall every Sunday at 12 pm while the [Japanese](/wiki/Japanese_people) fellowship meets every Sunday at 2.30 pm by the Singapore Japanese Christian Fellowship. Additionally, a youth service will be conducted for children aged 12-19 during the 10:15 am service on Sundays and [sunday schools](/wiki/Sunday_School) is also applied for children aged 3 to 11 during both 8 am and 10:15 services. ## Courses A number of courses are run at St George's Church, including Alpha, Christianity Explored and Moore College theology courses. ## Notable members - [Tony Tan Keng Yam](/wiki/Tony_Tan_Keng_Yam), the 7th President of Singapore. - Christianity portal - Bible portal - [Anglicanism](/wiki/Anglicanism) - [Anglican Communion](/wiki/Anglican_Communion) - [Anglican Diocese of Singapore](/wiki/Anglican_Diocese_of_Singapore) - [Bishop of Singapore](/wiki/Bishop_of_Singapore) - [Book of Common Prayer](/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer) - [Christianity in Singapore](/wiki/Christianity_in_Singapore) - [Church of England](/wiki/Church_of_England) - Saint George: Devotions, traditions and prayers - *Anglican Theology*, Chapman, Mark.
